STATE OF NEBRASKA Fourteenth Biennial Report OF THK Superintendent OP THK Hospital for the Insane of Nebraska NORFOLK, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium ending November 30, 1916

SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF RESIDENT OFFICERS G. E. Charlton Superintendent H. R. Carson First Assistant Physician R, H. Foster Second Assistant Physician and Pathologist A. J. Gutzmer Steward Bestha Ludwig Matron Laura Hill Bookkeeper

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 279 HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE OF NEBRASKA Norfolk, Nebraska To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morchead, Governor, and to the Honorable members of the Board of Commis - sioners of State Institutions, Howard Kennedy, Henry Gerdes and Silas A. Holcomb: Gentlemen: The fourteenth biennial report of the superintendent for the two years ending November 30, 1916, is herewith pre - sented, with the statistics required by the Board of Commis - sioners of State Institutions. Your attention is directed to the fact that the report deals largely with affairs begun under the administration of my predecessor, Dr. William D. Guttery. Dr. Guttery was suspended from the superintendency at the request of the Board of Commissioners of State In - stitutions on January 8, 1916, and Dr. H. R. Carson, assistant superintendent, was made acting superintendent by the same act. On March 4, 1916, the temporary suspension was made permanent. You honored me with the position thus rendered vacant and I assumed charge of the hospital as superintend - ent on March 17, 1916. At the beginning of the period under consideration, there were present in the hospital 457 patients, 226 males and 231 females. During the period 370 have been admitted, 237 males and 133 females. There were on parole at the be - ginning of the period 52 patients, 26 males and 26 females; on the escape list at the beginning of the biennium there were 13 males; total belonging to the institution December 1, 1914, 892 patients, 502 males and 390 females. There were discharged during the present biennium 146 patients, 81 males

SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF 280 and 65 females; transferred to other institutions 3 males; died in the institution 90 patients, 60 males and 30 females; died on parole 3 females; paroled and not returned 66 pa - tients, 34 males and 32 females ; and escaped and not returned 15 males. Population on the last day of the period was 569 patients, 309 males and 260 females. This shows an increase of 112 patients for the past biennium, which is the largest increase in any one biennium since the establishment of the institution. HEALTH Taken as a whole the general health of the patients has been very good. At the beginning of the biennium there were a few cases of smallpox extending from the previous bien - nium. These cases were all cleared up by the first of the year 1914. There were no fatalities from this epidemic. In the early part of March, 1916, there were three cases of scar - let fever on the male hospital ward. These cases were isolated and placed under quarantine. Of the three cases, one nurse and two patients, one patient died. In September, 1916, we had one case of typhoid fever. Other than this we have been free from infectious and contagious diseases. EMPLOYMENT OF PATIENTS UWe have been giving patients who are capable and will - to work such employment as we were able to devise, — farm work, kitchen, laundry, dairy, garden, and engine room. Occupation is generally recognized as a potent factor in treat - ment of mental diseases and we expect the next two years to start some industrial work whereby more of our men and women may find suitable occupation. AMUSEMENTS We have had the usual amusements, such as you are familiar with — w r eekly dances, moving picture shows, baseball games, etc. IMPROVEMENTS The new addition to the west wing for male patients, provided for by the last legislature, is now completed and has been occupied since February, 1916. The equipment and

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 281 arrangement of this building is excellent. It provides for 75 patients, 39 of whom have individual rooms. The remaining thirty-six are slept in three well lighted and ventilated dormi - tories. For each of the three floors there is a large airy day - hall and in the basement a large dining room. The building is of fire proof construction. The new cottage for women is now under construction and is nearing completion. This building bids fair to be one of the most beautiful and useful buildings we have. Eighty acres of land, joining the State's land on the west, were purchased as provided by the last legislature. A four-room cottage with basement, built of cement blocks made by patients, has been built and is now occupied by the second physician. An eighty-foot addition to the green house has been com - pleted and is now in service. The vegetable cellar has been remodelled and equipped with double decks, thus enabling us better to care for vege - tables. There has been considerable work done on the barns, sheds, and lots in the way of finishing and repairing. Much painting has been done on the wards and many bedsteads have been painted. The sewerage from the south row of buildings is empty - ing into a septic tank which in turn empties into an under - ground drainage system, for irrigation. We experienced no trouble with the tank but had considerable trouble with the underground drainage. It seems the laterals running off from the main line were unable to take care of all the sewerage causing the flooding of some of the low places near the end of these laterals. We are adding new laterals and hope to overcome this difficulty. The Russell Sewerage System used for the new west wing has given considerable trouble, stopping up and flood - ing the basement floor. This is a guaranteed system and we have taken the matter up with the Russell people.

282 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF TRAINING SCHOOL FOR NURSES The Training School for Nurses has been continued, the medical staff and head nurse all devoting much time to the classes. The entire senior classes of 1915 and 1916 passed their final examinations. 286 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF TAILOR, SHOE AND MATTRESS SHOPS In the report of the work accomplished in the tailor, shoe and mattress shops all work was done by patients. The amount of work accomplished is as follows: Three hundred and twenty-one mattresses were made. Of that number eighty-nine were new. The balance were soiled mattresses which were thoroughly cleansed and ren- ovated and new covers put on. In the shoe shop 419 shoes were repaired. Tailor Shop Repaired Aprons 28 Overalls 528 Bags, laundry 10 Pants 841 Bags (with drawstrings) 80 Restraint jackets 16 Bedspreads 18 Rugs 58 Bed ticks 311 Straight suits 7 Blankets 24 Suits (and pressed) 2:' Coats 327 Sweaters 6 Coats, duck 11 Ties 21 Curtains 5 Vests 60 Jackets Ill Manufactured Barber sheets 2 Laundry tags 16 Baseball bases 3 Pillow tops 5 Bed ticks, double 7 Suspenders 36 Bed ticks, single 132 Window shades 20 Bibs 10 Blankets marked 97 Jackets (extra large) 6 EMPLOYEES An increase in the pay roll is inevitable, it seems to me. There are a number of our employees who have given us faithful service for a number of years and must receive ade - quate increase in pay if we are to retain them. The employment of competent and efficient nurses and attendants is one of the most vital problems connected with the management of an institution of this kind. The demand for all labor has been increased the last two years, and with this demand, wages have materially increased, until in certain seasons of the year the procuring of desirable and proficient help has become a serious problem.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 287 We believe that a merit system with sufficient funds whereby better salaries could be paid to reward faithful efforts should be introduced. In our estimate for appro priations we are asking for an increase in employees' wages CASH RECEIPTS In the following table of cash receipts of the institution it will be noted that $10,678.78 has been collected for main- tenance. The maintenance law passed by the last legislature went into effect July, 1915. However, at this institution no maintenance was collected until in April, 1916. We are now collecting from 9 per cent of our population, which is about the average per cent collected in other states for mainten- ance for their insane. 288 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF FARM AND GARDEN A detailed report of the produce from farm and garden will be found among 'the statistical tables at the end of this report. NEEDS Our present bakery, kitchen, employees' dining room, amusement hall, laundry and boiler room were built in 1886. With our present population these original buildings that were built for a population of about three hundred have become inadequate. Bearing in mind the importance of all these units to an institution, and, realizing the impossibility of repairing or remodeling all in one biennium, we recommend at this time only that which we feel is of the most pressing need. STATEMENT OF ESTIMATED APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE BIENNIUM BEGINNING APRIL 1, 1917, to MARCH 31 (wcl.), 1919 Ordinary Expenses Salary' of Superintendent $5,000.00 Salary of Assistant Physician 3,000.00 Salary of 2d Physician 2.700.00 Salary' of 3rd Physician 2,400.00 Salary of Chaplain 480.00 Salary of Steward 3,000.00 Salary of Superintendent of Nurse: 1,800.00 Salary of Matron 1,200.00 $ 19,580.00 Wages of Employees 74,420.00 Maintenance 228,000.00 Repairs and Improvements 5,000.00 $327,000.00 Extraordinary Expenses Land $ 31,400.00 New Buildings for Housing Inmates.... 75,000.00 Power Plant 60,000.00 Bake Shop _ 5,000.00 Silo 600.00 Sewer 3,000.00 $175,000.00 Grand Total _ $502,000.00

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 289 The foregoing recommendations are based upon a 13% increase of our present population, which is 645. The appro - priation is figured on a 3(Kr increase of cost of all commod - ities over the per capita of past biennium. Our figures for the per capita cost is $14.16, (officers, employees, inmates), for the past biennium. RECOMMENDATIONS We wish to recommend the addition of another phy - sician to our present medical staff. The population of this institution has increased to the degree that our present staff of two physicians is not able properly to examine, treat and give individual attention to each patient. On the male side of the house there are at present three hundred and nine patients. This is forty more than was originally intended should be housed in these buildings. We have, however, crowded beds into the large dormitories on wards 1 and 2, and have at the time this report is written two vacant beds. By the time the legislature meets we will have had to refuse the admittance of male patients. In view of these facts, we are requesting an appropriation to con - struct a building with a capacity of one hundred patients. Our present power plant is of poor construction and is too small for our present needs. As the demands upon this important unit are increasing year by year we believe it would be unwise to repair or add to this combustible building. We, therefore, recommend a new power plant. With our increased population and new buildings our present sewerage system will be inadequate, and we propose to relieve the septic tank by running a sewerage line east from our buildings for a distance of six hundred yards, and then ditching the sewerage over the different fields. We are asking for an appropriation of three thousand dollars for this work. The bake shop is too small for our present needs. The oven is in very bad condition, having been in use for some thirty years, and we are asking for an appropriation of five thousand dollars for a new bake shop.

SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF 290 The farm at this institution now carries one hundred and two head of Holstein cattle, pure bred and grades ; seven - teen horses and mules and one hundred and thirty-five hogs, of various ages. The needs of the institution call for a larger number of both cattle and hogs, milch cows especi - ally. We are now milking thirty-two cows, but can use to the advantage of the institution fifty. However, more land will be needed to carry this number and produce for them. bThe volume of milk as food would greatly reduce the it of maintenance. Pork can be produced more eco - mically on a ration of alfalfa and corn than any other article of food. The soil adjoining the State farm is especi - ally adapted to raising both these crops. The State is at present renting one hundred and twenty acres of land, eighty acres of which it has more than paid for at the present value of rental. We can produce our own food at an institution of this kind for much less than it costs to buy it. In view of these facts why shouldn't the State own sufficient land to pro - duce all food needed for the inmates? The benefits to the institution, and the good and sound economy from the view point of a State management will be understood when it is remembered that among the inmates at this institution are to be found a considerable number of the best farm laborers in the State. We recommend the purchase of two hundred and ten acres of land at this time. We recommend the erection of a new two hundred-ton CONCLUSION In conclusion I wish to thank his Excellency the Gover - nor, and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions for their assistance, wise counsel, and advice. To the officers and employees of the hospital my sincere thanks are due for their support and co-operation. Respectfully submitted George E. Charlton, Superintendent.
